quote: Dogs are able to solve this kind of problem, but their level of success is lower than it is in visible displacement problems.
In the second step of shaping, sessions were divided into 30 discrete trials where the animal had to touch the object near each of the three identical white screens.
The visual cues displayed on the front panels of these screens were also different.
Twenty purebred adult dogs (Canis familiaris, 15 females and 5 males) that belonged to private owners and breeders, were used in this experiment.
In Experiment 2, dogs were tested on the same types of invisible transposition as the ones in Experiment I.
The major difference between cats and dogs appeared in substitution transpositions.
